title: 109_hr2297
content:
The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." is a condensed summary of the section that includes the short title, findings, and purposes of the document. The "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act" recognizes the Arabia Mountain area's natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources. It emphasizes partnerships between public and private entities for resource management. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain are highlighted for their conservation efforts. The Miners Creek Preserve in Lithonia, Georgia, showcases early human activity with evidence of granite mining history. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to preserve and promote natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area, including Arabia Mountain and Panola Mountain. It also supports the development of these resources in collaboration with Georgia and surrounding counties. The State is working with DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry to develop and implement a program for managing cultural, historical, and land resources in the heritage area. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Heritage area refers to the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area. Management entity is the DeKalb County Parks and Recreation Department or its successor. Management plan is the plan developed for the heritage area. Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. State means the State of Georgia. SEC. 3. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA established in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is the management entity.

SEC. 4. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF THE MANAGEMENT ENTITY. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests and gives priority to preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia is responsible for preserving resources within the area, encouraging local governments to adopt land use policies consistent with the management plan, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting an annual report on accomplishments and finances, and allowing audits of all records related to the expenditure of funds. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must allow audits of all records related to the expenditure of Federal funds by other organizations. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property, but the entity can use funds from other Federal laws for authorized purposes. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, agencies, and organizations, and include an inventory of resources to be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should include an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, a program for implementation, and a description and evaluation of the management entity. This plan must be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding until the plan is submitted. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it, and if disapproved, the entity will be advised of the reasons for the disapproval. After the Secretary approves a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the plan for approval within 90 days. No funds can be expended without approval of revisions to the plan. The management entity must submit recommendations for plan revisions within 90 days of plan approval. No funds can be used for proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. SEC. 7. EFFECT ON CERTAIN AUTHORITY. The Act ensures that no new regulations are imposed on the heritage area that are more stringent than existing regulations, and it does not grant zoning powers to the management entity. SEC. 8 outlines the requirements for including private property in the Heritage Area, stating that property owners must be notified and give consent for preservation, conservation, or promotion. Property owners can request the removal of their property from the area. SEC. 9 focuses on protecting private property within the Heritage Area. The Act ensures that private property owners are not required to allow public access or modify existing laws regarding access. It also states that designation as a Heritage Area does not create liability for property owners. Additionally, it clarifies that participation in the Heritage Area is not mandatory for property owners within its boundaries. The Heritage Area boundaries do not grant regulatory authority over land use or viewshed to the Secretary, National Park Service, or management entity. SEC. 10. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 authorized for this Act, with $1,000,000 limit per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50% of project costs.

SEC. 11. Termination of Authority: Secretary's grant and assistance authority under this Act ends on September 30, 2016.
